review.title: Experiments with POS Tagging Code-mixed Indian Social Media Text
review.abstract: This paper presents Centre for Development of Advanced Computing Mumbai's (CDACM) submission to the NLP Tools Contest on Part-Of-Speech (POS) Tagging For Code-mixed Indian Social Media Text (POSCMISMT) 2015 (collocated with ICON 2015). We submitted results for Hindi (hi), Bengali (bn), and Telugu (te) languages mixed with English (en). In this paper, we have described our approaches to the POS tagging techniques, we exploited for this task. Machine learning has been used to POS tag the mixed language text. For POS tagging, distributed representations of words in vector space (word2vec) for feature extraction and Log-linear models have been tried. We report our work on all three languages hi, bn, and te mixed with en.

metadata.title: Experiments with POS Tagging Code-mixed Indian Social Media Text

sections.text: This article introduces the submission of the Centre for Development of Advanced Computing Mumbai (CDACM) to the NLP Tools Contest on Part-Of-Speech (POS) Tagging For Code-mixed Indian Social Media Text (POSCMISMT) 2015 (together with ICON 2015). We submitted the results for Hindi (hi), Bengali (bn) and Telugu (te) languages mixed with English (en). In this article we described our approaches to the POS tagging techniques we used for this task. Machine learning was used to highlight the mixed text at the POS. At the POS tagging, distributed word representations in the vector space (word2vec) for feature extraction and loglinear models were tried out. We report on our work in all three languages hi, bn and mixed with en.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In this paper we present our experiments for POS tagging code mixed Indian social media text. The development of social media platforms such as blogs, micro-blogs (e.g. Twitter) and chats (e.g. Facebook messages) has created many new sources of access to information and language technologies, but the same has presented many new challenges, making it one of the most important current areas of research. Most of the Indians and many other nonEnglish speakers around the world do not always use Unicode to write something on social media, they use translation techniques and often add English elements through code mixing and Anglicisms, and mix multiple languages to express their thoughts.

sections.heading: 2 Data-sets
sections.text: For the experiments, we used 80% of the training data shared by POSCMISMT, which is described in detail in Table 1. Tests for the experiments were performed on the remaining 20% data, but the final transmission system was trained on the overall data. Systems submitted were evaluated by the organizers on the basis of a test corpus.

sections.heading: 3 Experiments and Results
sections.text: We have used the Stanford POS Tagger (Toutanova and Manning, 2000; Toutanova et al., 2003), which is available on the Stanford Natural Language Processing Group website for restricted training and results submission, and unrestricted training and results submissions have been conducted with word2vec (Mikolov et al., 2013) and WEKA (Hall et al., 2009).

sections.heading: 3.1 POS Tagging using Stanford POS tagger: Constrained
sections.text: We trained Stanford POS taggers based on the train data provided. Basically, this POS tagger learns from highlighted text a log-linear conditional probability model using a maximum entropy method. The POS tag of the input word is then decided by the model based on the context and surrounding tags of the word. The architecture (archproperty) we used for the training was: Words (-2, 2), Order (1), Prefix (6), Suffix (6), Unicode forms (1).

sections.heading: 3.2 POS tagging using Machine Learning: Unconstrained
sections.text: We used WEKA to experiment with the application of various machine learning techniques to the POS tagging problem. Various combinations of the following word features were used for training and testing the system: 1. Language of the word 2. Language of the previous word 3. Language of the next word 4. POS tags of the previous two words5. POS tags of the next two wordsimilarities 6. Position of the word in sentencesIn a sentence with the length L, words at positions 1, 2, L and L-1 were assigned the required number of default identifiers for previous and next languages as well as POS tags. For the POS tag of the next word, we used a distributed representation of the words in the vector space. We trained a word2vec model based on traction and test corpus detailed in Table 1. For the POS tag of the next word, we followed one of the following steps: 1. The word was searched from the list of training data when the most common word was found.

sections.heading: 4 Submission to the Shared Task
sections.text: Table 2 shows that the decision tree of J48 yielded better results and was therefore used to train the final submission system. Submitted results were evaluated by the organisers and presented in detail by the organisers in Table 3.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and Feature Work
sections.text: In this article, we introduced two techniques for POS marking of code-mixed Indian social media texts. The method used for restricted transmission is doing well, but for lack of high-quality training data, there is not much to do with it. On the other hand, the use of distributed vector representation of words in feature engineering could allow us to use unlabeled data for training. Results are encouraging and future work can focus on obtaining more social media corpus and using it to better represent features.
